```{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)
```

## R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

```{r readdata}
aphid=read.csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Cuddington-Lab/thermal-experiments/refs/heads/main/dataset_autocorrelation_aphids.csv")
head(aphid)
str(aphid)

#change Treatment to factor rather than numeric
aphid$Treatment=as.factor(aphid$Treatment)

# note: only seems to be two levels?

# this is also where you should eliminate/tag any data that you are not using
```

```{r sumreplicates}
aphid$plantsum=rowSums(aphid[,c("Aphid_count_1","Aphid_count_2","Aphid_count_3")], na.rm=TRUE)

aphid$petrisum=rowSums(aphid[,c("Petridish_Alive_count_1","Petridish_Alive_count_2","Petridish_Alive_count_2.1")], na.rm=TRUE)

head(aphid$plantsum)
head(aphid$petrisum)
```

## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r plots, echo=FALSE}
par(mfrow=c(1,2))
aphid0=aphid[aphid$Treatment=="0",]
plot(x=aphid0$Mean_temperature, y=aphid0$plantsum, col=aphid0$Technician, bty="l", xlab="temperature", ylab="offspring")
aphid95=aphid[aphid$Treatment=="0.95",]
plot(x=aphid95$Mean_temperature, y=aphid95$plantsum, col=aphid95$Technician, bty="l", xlab="temperature", ylab="offspring")
```

Note that the `echo = FALSE` parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.


```{r stats}
par(mfrow=c(1,1))
summary(glm(plantsum~Treatment, data=aphid[aphid$Mean_temperature==15,]))

table(aphid[aphid$Mean_temperature==15,"plantsum"])

plot(plantsum~Treatment,data=aphid[aphid$Mean_temperature==15,], ylab="offspring", xlab="autocorrelation") 

```
